w:r.w:t: Article
An Article is a substantial novel research study, with a complex story often involving several techniques or approaches.
Format
Main text – up to 3,000 words, excluding abstract, online Methods, references and figure legends.
Abstract – up to 150 words, unreferenced.
Display items – up to 6 items (figures and/or tables).
Article should be divided as follows:
Introduction (without heading)
Results
Discussion
Online Methods. ​
Results and online Methods should be divided by topical subheadings; the Discussion does not contain subheadings.
References – as a guideline, we typically recommend up to 50.
Articles include received/accepted dates.
Articles may be accompanied by supplementary information.
Articles are peer reviewed.
I can’t decide if this term fits here. To me serendipity is a rough synonym of “happy coincidence”. I don’t think that’s quite right, however, it’s a colourful word so I kind of like it

I like the colourful tone of it, and also the alignment with the notion of “opportunity” in ensemble of opportunity. The availability of data is therefore a happy coincidence because it means data is available. Alternatively, we could find a phrasing with the word “happenstance” :)
perhaps here also listing assumptions around resource usage, time resolution, and energy system characteristics

It is of course a matter of interpretation, but (preferred/energy) energy system characteristics would typically not be part of the quality characteristics but rather of the relevance characteristics.
That’s good.
Related to ‘diversity’. Should it be mentioned in the abstract already, that this method (obviously?) does not account for anything
not included at all
in the original database - it at best gives high weights to the existing ‘outliers’ / unique studies.
I don’t disagree, but the word count of the abstract (150 words, unfortunately) does.
When likelihood is available, like for temperature, wouldn’t it make some sense that R(i) is P(i<theta)
It would, but as we are leaving the exact choice of scenario metric m_i open, it would be distracting if it were to be added here. Maybe something we can include further down.
Can we say anything about the exponential form?
I adjusted it to a stretched exponential for more adaptability and highlighted it is an example. As we don’t apply it in practice, we don’t need to spend more on it here.

That’s right. But doesn’t the same hold true for ‘relevance’, above? Admittedly, less so, because creating a good research question itself is the key step. But let’s say you want to look at scenarios with ‘high well-being’; with no scenarios reporting ‘well-being’ as a variable, what variables to use to estimate this, how to weight it, etc.
I imagine you don’t want to go into this, and probably shouldn’t.
But it might be something for the discussion; assessing relevance criteria can also be an expert judgement.
Excellent point - I’ll see if I can include it further down.

wouldn't this be a multiplication of distance criteria? so prodsum_{j,k} v_{j,k} of j distance criteria of k quality metrics? in any case i would generalize beyond emissions and energy or feasibility trends
I think it remains unclear what this notations f(d(vi,vj)) means, and there’s no worked example because the paper does not use it in the end (it just uses binary).
It is also not clear in this ‘distance’ formulation that often, what is used is ranges of allowed values, not one specific estimated reference observation.
What is the logic for specifying an exponential decay for relevance (outside a range), but not for quality (where you do binary)?
Couldn’t a similar form as for R(i) also work for Q(i)?
Or another option (inbetween binary and exponential decay) could be a sigmoidal form?
Have changed this to now cover this together with Matt’s suggestion.

f(d(vk,E)) now indicates that the weight is a function of a generalized distance between a scenario metric’s value vk and an expert assessment of a set of quality measures E, which can also refer to ranges.
I agree that we do not work out all examples and options here, but have changed the description to be more widely applicable. If reviewers ask about this, we can elaborated during the revisions.
Additionally, why an expansive treatment of multiple variables and how they can be weighed differently in diversity, and not here?
brevity
So somewhere should be the point that both quality and even relevance, can be multidimensional (without each dimension needing to be equally important)
I included this further down in the discussion.
add in sentence about 'vetting for' or actively readjusting for high diversity in outcomes
This could be a weakness.
If I understand things well, for C1, this choice determines the outcome (“bias corrections reveal more stringent emission milestones”).
In combination with diversity weighting.
This is because the peakT distribution of the C1 scenarios is very dense close to the threshold, and very sparse far away from the threshold. Now, you are weighing those far from the threshold more.
(I do not know the starting distribution of scenarios for C2 by heart; I suspect it is a bit more uniformly distributed.)
-> To confirm, and for transparency, I think it would be good to have the peakT distributions (prior and posterior) also shown.
If you would have applied R(i) with the e^-((m-theta)/theta) setup with R(i)=1 for C1, and 0<R(i)<1 for scenarios outside C1, then you would get the opposite outcome.
As suggested before, another option is to use exceedance probabilities as the R(i), where the standard AT6 cutoffs could be translated to weight = 0.5 (if you don’t want to do P(Tpeak<1.5)=R(i)).
I am not sure yet what results that would give.
We’ll plot the prior vs posterior

The alternative R(i) influence described is only correct if the threshold is taken at the same spot. If one truly reflects on the deep uncertainty of the temperature distribution (e.g., what is the uncertainty in the MAGICC distribution?) this threshold would decline.
Using probabilities is possible, but unsure if users will intuitively understand what it means.
Points 2 and 3 could be explored for the revisions.
Both of the latter two options would reduce some of the arbitrariness of the scenario grouping process somewhat?
Compared to what you have now, you would have more scenarios in each category (1 scenario will count towards multiple categories), and thus will lead to a higher density in the low weight area
See reflection above

Here, this just means “diversity weighting”, right? No other weighting is applied?
Yes - clarified now
Here also, I feel like the conclusion here is very strongly dependent on the choice made for R(i).
R(i) doesn’t change from AR6. So this conclusion can’t be the outcome of that choice.

Of course, if we would change R(i) numbers would change, but this would answer a different question and not be fully comparable. Depending on the choice of R(i) this could shift values towards higher or lower parts of the distribution.

Can you really call it a "bias correction"? Maybe "reweighting" is more approxiate. Less sexy obviously.
I assume we won't have a paper ready yet when you want to submit this

So this is quite difficult to see. In fact, some of the quantiles do not even change -> probably because the outer edges were unique enough anyway. I would say that not in some cases, but in all cases, the shift is relatively small.

But then again, wherever there is a signal, it points to the same direction. Do you have (words) room to discuss why that is the case? Why is it that when looking at a more balanced and qualified scenario ensemble, you see more ambition? This is not trivial I would say, you could also think of the opposite. Is it because you can only have a late NZ year and compliant with 1.5 deg in vary specific energy system configuration, which will then be flagged by your algorithm as close together?
So this is mostly re-iterating the observation, but not an explanation (not a problem, but see my last comment)
Relatively difficult to read/understand.
..which is a form of bias in itself. Hence, to call your methods a 'bias-correction' could be misleading.
Not only that. Also that sometimes there is simply expert-consensus on certain developments, which is important to be reflected in the ensemble analysis, but is filtered using your distance approach.

The violins look almost symmetric in some cases. Hence, maybe the redistribution is not the most interesting thing here, but a careful look at scenarios that get a high or actually a very low distance metric. E.g., is it mainly the NDC scenarios or other policy-prescribed scenarios, that are found redundant? Is that by construct / intentional, or does that point to a flaw in our community?
Figure does not load for me, so maybe I'm missing something.

I like the work (don't get me wrong!), but there are no clear/strong conclusions. That could be fine, but potentially you could have a closer look at how the distribution of certain models, projects or policy assumptions (like you're doing in SI 3) change -> what do you notice there? Which scenarios get a low or high diversity score? What do we learn from that?
